page.title: 02DONCASTER CARR'S ECOLOGY
page.content: Doncaster, Balby and Potteric Carrs are on an{ecology roundabout.}In the time of Henry VIII the area was part of Hatfield Chase: a marsh and part of the largest deer chase in England. In the following centuries a duck decoy was built and the ducks caught were given to the poor of the area. The decoy went when the area was effectively drained by John Smeaton in the 1760s but the place name survives in Decoy Bank and Decoy Sidings. Drainage turned the land over to farming with hedges, fields and small plantations of trees. 100 years later this all changed when the area was covered by railways and colliery deposits. The full circle was turned when Rossington pit to the S.W. undermined the area in the 1960s causing subsidence which returned it to wetland marsh.
